data.text: How to Deal with Dog Bite when Cycle Touring?
Got bitten by a stay dog today in Istanbulü•∫. How do you handle dogs coming to you when cycling?
I squirt them in the face with my water bottle

data.text: We use air horns (klaxtons). Let the dog/s get as close as you dare, aim the klaxton in their direction, give about a half second blast. . . You may have to repeat the process a second time. They stop because they don't know WTF that noise is and they choose to not deal with it.
data.author: Chuck Atkinson

data.text: I asked a doctor once if I should get rabies shots before my cycling tours around the world . His answer was that the only people he ever saw in hospital with dog bites were those who insisted on talking to stray dogs. Stopping and talking to them in the illusion that they are looking for a new friend may sound nice. But it's pretty much the dumbest thing you can do.
data.author: Claus Andersen

data.text: Ma'am...I don't give a damn what an animals nature is...in nature if they attack the wrong animal they die. Dogs learn very quickly. Spray their nose full of pepper spray and they will never bother people again.

data.text: If another animal (that animal can also be a human) attacks you, you have the natural right to defend yourself in whatever means you want. If you hurt or kill the attacking animal in the process, then be it so. There are very few animals which are stupid enough to attack other animals, including humans, just like that. Dogs are one of these stupid animals. For comparison, a wolf would never, just for fun, attack a human; only if he is starving. Most animals only attack other animals for food or because they feel serously threatened.
data.author: Wulfram Georg Tanner

data.text: Your comments make me and the friends around me very very sadüôÅ.... in what kind of world are you living..? I just read attack, death, kick, defend, bite, spray, ... stop and look around you. the world is full of war. But we are cyclists and we have to make statements for a good and positive world of respect eachother. Animals are fragile creatures. Treat them with respect and you get back the same. Remember - if you cycle, you're a guest in the country you are at that time. You have no rights to harm other human or animals. So stay calm, go your way, enjoy harmony and piece and let the place as good as it was before or better.üêï

data.text: A service dog in the modern sense is usually for people claiming they have mental health issues. It's all one big racket for women to always have their mini dogs next to them all the time. I have a therapist friend who writes the form for them.

data.text: a service dog and an emotional support animal aren't the same thing, people like to miss use the terms to be allowed to bring their pets with them to private businesses that don't allow for people bringing in their pets.
data.author: Michael Castro

data.text: how the fuck can a dog emotionally support some one what a load of shit
data.author: Charlie Brown

data.text: The "reasoning" is that since the person has some mental issue like PTSD for example and the presence of the animal that they are comfortable with is enough to help them keep they shi* together. Of course, in most cases it's BS, a service animal is usually specific for visual or auditory handicapped people (as the dog helps them get around) and it's a large dog like a Golden Retriever or German Shepard, not a little hand dog. The problem is that legislators have not defined registration mandates and requirements so anyone can just claim their little dog is an emotional support animal since there is no requirement to show tags or IDs or anything so it's easier for people to scam the businesses.
data.author: Michael Castro

data.text: A service dog is specifically trained to assist a person. For example, small dogs can alert a person that a seizure is coming on. They can alert a deaf person that there is a car approaching, or a person calling out. Larger dogs can be used for support if a person needs assistance with standing. And, of course, dogs of various sizes can be trained to guide a person with visual difficulties. There are many specific services that a trained animal can provide to assist a person with a disability. An emotional support dog can help a person who has PTSD, anxiety disorders, or other issues which can be debilitating.

data.text: I have good this problem sometimes in India. As long as you recognize them not a problem. I just stop turn my bike and chase them and they are really running in the other direction as fast as possible. I go also sometimes jogging on the beach in India and there is one place where I get attacked by several dogs (around Gokarna). That is more dangerous, sometimes up to 6 at ones. I have for such cases a stick with me and very often at the beginning of my time on the beach a slingshot. You can take the stick and chase them: Works very good but takes a lot of energy. Better take the slingshot and hit the first one shot to the second one and the game is over. After repeating the game the second time next day it is over: They don‚Äôt like you anymore for the next weeks, they are very much afraid of you as you can hit them at 15 m, you like a God for them now but not a good one. They run away at the time they see me. But there are countries with bigger dogs which are not so easy to handle.

data.text: Stop cycling and stare at the dog while putting the bicycle between you and the dog. It doesn't seem to matter if you scream or stay silent... as long as you stare at the dog they typically get quite and lower their heads. I once stopped a huge Rottweiler charging me with just a strong "No!" while pointing at his home... then the dog turned around and ran home. ‚òùüèΩ You're going to need to get rabies shots now... üòñ They're expensive and painful. Unless you can proof that the dog that bite you doesn't have rabies. Rabies is one of the worst diseases that you can die from. üò≥

data.text: Absolutely right. I cycled right across Asia and had this problem on numerous occasions. I always stopped put the bike between myself and the dog and stared them down. It worked every time. The only time it probably wouldn‚Äôt work is if you meet a deranged animal. In that case nothing will stop them. Never turn your back on them or cycle away when they are chasing you.

data.text: Stop cycling immediately. They are in it fir the chase. I had hundreds of occasions where I was faced with very aggressive dogs and just stopping seemed to defuse the attacks. Then move off slowly. I also used a Y shaped stick as a bike stand and piece of innertube to hold the front brake on. This had many uses. 1 to stand the bike up 2 to fend off dogs and 3 by putting it side ways on the rear rack with a flag or yellow vest it helped to keep vehicles from coming to close. You can just seen the stick in the photo. To note we never had to hit anything or even pull out from the rack but just gave us a piece of mind.

data.text: Pretend to pick up a rock if they start chasing you. That will send them running away. You do not need to throw a rock. Pretending is enough, as they know what it means if you kneel down and pretend to pick up a rock. If you stop and talk to them, then better get a rabies vaccination in advance, because a rabid dog will bite even the friendliest person, as they are sick and afraid.

data.text: A firm ‚Äúno‚Äù has stopped most dogs for me, frequently pointing at the same time. I will also stop pedaling if they keep coming after me shouting ‚Äúno.‚Äù I‚Äôve only had to put the bike between me and the dog a couple of times. Then I just walk out of it‚Äôs territory until I can get back on my bike again. The one dog that was extremely aggressive while on my bike, was extremely friendly after I was off my bike. The owner told me a cyclist had hit it with a pump once so now it really hates cyclists! All those recommending physically engaging with the dog, think about that!!

data.text: The dog is fixated on you as a threat. Breaking that fixation is the goal. Point at the dog with a commanding ‚ÄúNo!‚Äù. If ineffective turn your bike towards the dog repeat, No. Stop with your bicycle between you and dog and repeat.

data.text: I was told to slow down then take off fast...but this is easier said than done. I was almost bit by a pitbul once and it was very scary, I was riding at resting speed and when I see him he was full speed coming from my left. I didn't think about stop and go, I took off as fast as I could and he almost caught me. I didn't have any gear and on a road bike it was flat so I was able to accelerate really fast. What got me though was that here in Michigan there are a lot of invisible fences so typically a dog will bark run up and stop. I still keep an eye on them since this one kept running at me, crossed the road, almost got hit by a car and almost bit me. The following week he did it again though this time I expected it so I picked up speed before and he wasn't able to get as close. I then found the house on Google maps and reported it to the police. Didn't happen again.

data.text: As professional dog behavioralist and trainer of +20 years, their natural instinct is to chase something that is moving fast passed them - especially the strays or farm dogs. The noise of a bike, stakeboard, etc, triggers them. Chasing is their way of running you out of their personal space/territory. If you can stop, put yourself between the dog and the bike, do that. Get loud but not aggressively screaming - they will sense the fear. Don't make direct eye contact. Look left and right - with your head, not just the eyes and use a more calm and deeper voice to ease them. This usually diffuses most of them letting them know you aren't challenging them. Direct eye contact, as most of us already know, is seen as a challenge. Dogs typically attack (an attack is more than a nip/bite at your lower legs - it's multiple charges) as a last resort unless they have an underlying aggression/behavioral issue. A bite at the legs, as scary as it can be, and paibful, is usually confused with but isn't an aggression. It's an innate herding/territorial behavior. If they continue, and/or go for other parts of the body, that's a problem. In that case, throw away all your humanitarian beliefs and fight back if there is no other choice. As others have said, a loud airhorn is useful to confusing them and stop them in their track. An emergency whistle works just as well and is much smaller and easier to carry around your neck for quick response. You can also use a hiking pole to keep them focused on that (a retractable hiking pole has many other used such as a more reliable and sturdy kick stand for a loaded bike. Hitting an aggressive dog will only make they more mad and agressive. As a last resort, on a dog that is showing territorial aggression (one that won't leave you after a nip or after you stop and keeps trying to attack you), and you feel like it will end up even worse for you, use mace. It's uncomfortable (in the military it was used on us a few times in training) but it won't cause them permanent physical harm. After a bite, clean and cover the wound. Find a place to get a rabbies shot even if you recently had one done. Locals will help you with information even if you're in a remote area (except Patagonia, Pamir mountains, etc - which for such remote locations ALWAYS get a rabbies shot before you depart from home) Always get rabbits shots before you leave on tour unless the doctor says otherwise based on when you have your last shot.
data.author: Adir Sharon

data.text: Don't use wasp spray, or any other bug killing spray. It's posionous. It can kill them in a slow agonizing death. The the very least, more immediately, it can cause seizures

data.author: Dirk Wellmann

data.text: I just came back from Gran Canaria where dogs can be a problem in rural areas. Passing one property x5 dogs from Jack Russells to bigger hunting dogs went nuts. I was riding slowly up hill. Two of the dogs jumped over an 8 feet high fence by climbing on top of an out house. Once they came they all came, barking, growling, snarling after me. I immediately got off my bike and placed it between the dogs and me. A few of the mutts tried to get around my bike but I then shouted at them to go home! A few went but several remained, growling snarling trying to circle and get behind me to bit me. The owner of the property did not come out. They never do. I was scared. If I had had a gun I would have shot them as loose aggressive dogs are a menace at best and dangerous at worst. Eventually after standing still and shouting aggressively at them to go home and pointing to their property they left, but it was scary. I like dogs but being their dinner is not something I look forward to. I think next tour I take my walking poles so I can beat any dog that does give chase, gets too close and tries to bite me or my panniers. I would use them on owners as well as it is a pretty terrifying experience. I may well try to get some bear spray mace. I suppose you could empty a fuel bottle on them and then chuck a match at them BOOM!! Sorry but it's either them or me. I also have a Go Pro and hopefully have enough battery to capture the incident as evidence although on this occasion I did not have it set up. But get your wound seen to asap.
data.author: Alex Maudorn

data.text: Usually chasers comes in a 3 pack or less and are weak street dogs then a simple rod or stones can scare them away,depends on timing. More sofisticated defense like spray, sling shot, ultrasonic 125 decibels devices dog repellent work under certain circumstances. i mean with the Dog 125 decibels repellent if the Doberman is deaf you are in big trouble. My wife used to carry a rod and had success in anti-attacks. When i see them in advance, i stop to grab some stones to go through.
data.author: Jo En Pausa

data.text: Pepper spray first, knife second.

data.text: water in the face

data.text: I ride in hiking boots due to the off-road areas I ride in. It helps when I get stuck. They also make good dog deterants
data.author: Barnaby Taylor

data.text: I've had very good luck with an ultrasonic whistle, which many say is ineffective. But I've had to resort to a very small but potent Kimber mace pistol once when the former did not work.
data.author: Richard Cheatham

data.text: Squirt with my water from my water bottles
data.author: Israel Morris

data.text: Bites should be washed with classic soap, because it is alkaline. And it should heal from the inside, you can't close the wound with stitches.
data.author: Karl Gerber

data.text: Water bottle. Legal. Non lethal and very effective
data.author: Ken Beamer

data.text: My first instinct is to out run them but like running from the police, you damn well better get away! If that isn‚Äôt a good option, get off and talk to them like they are your dog. Be the dog whisperer! Usually calms them down . Also maybe pack along some dog biscuits and bear spray. Use as the situation dictates. Meanwhile find the owner and see if Fido had his rabies shot.
data.author: Ed Weingarten

data.text: Little bastards.
data.author: Neil Hornby

data.text: Get off your bike. Use your bike as a shield. If necessary pick up a few small stones and throw in their general direction. Talk to them whilst it‚Äôs all happening. This works for me and I‚Äôve been chased by dogs many times but never bitten.
data.author: Nick Potgieter

data.text: that‚Äôs exactly what I do!
data.author: Omare War

data.text: Yes! Also, after get of the bike, if you push the front brake and grab the back a little up (depending on the weight), you can use the back wheel to try to scare (or hit in extreme situations) the dog. Talking loud, throwing stones in their general direction or trowing water to them may also be useful. Never been bitten and i've been attacked many times.

data.text: You‚Äôre going to get bitten if you try and ride away. Dogs are built to bite on the run. This is their turf!

data.text: Probably first thing you wanna do like I did when I was surrounded by a pack of coyote, quickly dismount and put your bicycle way in front of you, like protecting your vital Oregons, but close enough so that if you have to, you can grab the saddle and lift it up from the back and suckrpunch them with the back wheel, doesn't matter if the wheel gets bent or whatever, use that back wheel with all your force, like you are angry as hell with your old classmates who picked on you, and you keep hitting them with it and scream at the top of your lungs to leave you the hell alone, I hope you feel better mate, do you think you need to go see a Dr

data.text: I hate countries that don‚Äôt take care of their stray dogs. I had so many problems with dogs in Greece, you see packs of them everywhere. ‚Ä¶I lied, I love Greece‚Ä¶hate the dogs

data.text: Go see a doctor, you don‚Äôt want to die from rabies, which is endemic in many of those countries.
data.author: Bruce Doherty

data.text: Shout as loudly as I can.
data.author: Eric Knudstrup

data.text: Try to talk to them calmly. If it doesn‚Äôt work and they are attacking, I have made a 4-in-1 bear spray, knife, taser, and flashing light combo weapon, which I had to use the last time I was in Turkey and the huge Kangor dogs over there were attacking me.
data.author: Tom O. Ro

data.text: If you're not sure you're faster than the dog (very difficult) it's usually better to slow down or stop, seeing you running triggers the animal's predatory instinct. I live in Italy where dogs are rarely dangerous and almost always I have my dog with me, I don't know what beasts you can meet over there, anyway I would suggest you to do some research about canine communication, every cic list should do it since fear often He makes you do exactly what you shouldn't.

data.text: At first stop your bicycle and stand shout at the dog as laud as possible make the dog afraid by shouting at him. I work as a delivery boy in food delivery by cycle and sometimes I work at the night times when the dogs are most active.. I never get bitten by any dog in my life. Only doing this thing.
data.author: Akash Paul

data.text: Mace/pepper spray works. Not nice but not lethal. I have only had to do it one in 30 years. All other times I was able to talk to them. I usually yell go home and that does good. Of course, you have to know the local language for it.
data.author: Jason Hutton

data.text: I would never use chemicals or violence on an animal, someone suggested an air horn, good luck!

data.text: Water bottle, spray horn, whistle, big stick!

data.text: In the case of the hellhound I came across outside Istanbul, as it happens, I channelled my inner Mark Cavendish and got the hell out. That's been the only one in forty years that got beyond annoying . .
